[File: network/framework/src/noise/handshake.rs] [Function: upgrade_inbound()] [Timestamp Payload Size] Does the check at line 434 for payload.len() != TIMESTAMP_SIZE properly reject all invalid timestamp sizes, or can an attacker send a payload with extra padding that passes this check? (Medium)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/handshake.rs] [Function: upgrade_inbound()] [Timestamp Conversion] When converting payload bytes to u64 timestamp using from_le_bytes(), can an attacker exploit integer overflow or endianness issues to bypass replay detection? (Medium)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/handshake.rs] [Function: upgrade_inbound()] [Replay Window] Between checking is_replay() and calling store_timestamp(), can two concurrent connections from the same public key both pass the replay check, allowing a replay attack during this race window? (Critical)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/handshake.rs] [Function: upgrade_inbound()] [RWLock Poisoning] If the anti_replay_timestamps RwLock is poisoned due to a panic in another thread, does the code properly handle this error, or can it lead to a denial of service? (Medium)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/handshake.rs] [Function: upgrade_inbound()] [Response Generation] When respond_to_client() fails, does the server properly terminate the connection without revealing sensitive information about its internal state in the error message? (Low)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/handshake.rs] [Function: upgrade_inbound()] [Write Failure] If socket.write_all() fails when sending the server response, does this leave the noise session in a state that could be exploited in a subsequent connection attempt? (Medium)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/handshake.rs] [Function: authenticate_inbound()] [Key Set Check] Does the peer.keys.contains() check at line 494 properly validate that the remote_public_key is genuinely part of the peer's key set, or can an attacker bypass this through set manipulation? (Critical)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Struct: NoiseStream] [Session Management] Can an attacker reuse a NoiseSession after it has been consumed by a NoiseStream, potentially allowing session replay or state confusion attacks? (Critical)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: new()] [Uninitialized State] Does the NoiseStream::new() function properly initialize all state machine states, or can uninitialized fields lead to undefined behavior when reading/writing? (Medium)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Enum: ReadState] [State Transition] Can an attacker cause the ReadState state machine to transition to an invalid state by sending malformed messages, potentially bypassing decryption or causing crashes? (High)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_read()] [Frame Length Parsing] When reading the 2-byte frame length at line 106, can an attacker send a frame_len of 0 to trigger the Eof(Err(())) state, causing a denial of service for legitimate connections? (Medium)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_read()] [Frame Length Overflow] Can an attacker send a frame_len larger than noise::MAX_SIZE_NOISE_MSG, causing a buffer overflow when reading into read_buffer at line 142? (Critical)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_read()] [Decryption Bypass] When read_message_in_place() fails with a decryption error, does the code properly clear sensitive data from read_buffer before transitioning to DecryptionError state? (Medium)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_read()] [EOF Handling] Is there a difference between ReadState::Eof(Ok(())) and ReadState::Eof(Err(())), and can an attacker exploit this distinction to cause inconsistent connection termination behavior? (Low)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_read()] [Copy Decrypted Frame] When copying decrypted data to the output buffer at line 174, can an attacker cause a buffer underflow or overflow by manipulating decrypted_len? (Critical)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_read()] [State Persistence] If poll_read() returns Poll::Pending, is the ReadState properly saved, or can concurrent reads interfere with each other, causing data corruption? (High)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Enum: WriteState] [State Transition] Can the WriteState state machine be exploited to encrypt data multiple times or skip encryption entirely by manipulating state transitions? (Critical)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_write_or_flush()] [Buffer Overflow] At line 256, when buffering data into write_buffer, can an attacker cause bytes_to_copy to exceed MAX_WRITE_BUFFER_LENGTH through integer overflow? (Critical)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Constant: MAX_WRITE_BUFFER_LENGTH] [Size Validation] Is MAX_WRITE_BUFFER_LENGTH correctly calculated as noise::decrypted_len(noise::MAX_SIZE_NOISE_MSG), or could size mismatches lead to buffer overflows? (High)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_write_or_flush()] [Encryption Failure] When write_message_in_place() fails, does the code at line 285 properly handle the encryption error, or can this lead to plaintext data being sent over the wire? (Critical)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_write_or_flush()] [Authentication Tag] Is the authentication tag correctly appended to the write_buffer at line 272, or can an attacker manipulate the tag to bypass integrity checks? (Critical)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_write_or_flush()] [Frame Length Calculation] When calculating frame_len at line 275, can integer overflow cause the frame_len to wrap around, leading to a mismatch between the length prefix and actual data size? (High)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_write_or_flush()] [TryInto Panic] Does the .expect() at line 278 properly handle cases where offset cannot fit in u16, or can this cause a panic and DoS when writing large messages? (Medium)

[File: network/framework/src/noise/stream.rs] [Function: poll_write_or_flush()] [Message Concatenation] At line 308, when concatenating frame_len_bytes and message_bytes, does this memory copy introduce vulnerabilities or timing side-channels? (Low)
